persona.name: Kai Mendoza

occupation.title: Part-time Barista / Retail Cafe Crew; Aspiring Indie Game Developer (side projects)
occupation.organization: Neighborhood coffeehouse and online indie projects
occupation.description: Kai works 25-30 hours a week as a barista at a locally owned cafe in an LA neighborhood — responsibilities include operating the espresso machine, cash handling, opening or closing shifts, inventory checks, light food prep, and helping train new hires. They are known for careful latte art and friendly customer conversations but sometimes struggles with long hours and late-night classes. Outside of the cafe job, Kai spends most of their free time developing small game prototypes in Unity and Godot, participating in weekend game jams, and testing builds with an online circle of players. They stream coding sessions and gameplay on Twitch occasionally to practice public-facing skills and to build a small following; revenue is minimal (tips/subs) but helps with monthly expenses. Kai also does occasional paid micro-gigs: user-testing for apps, annotating datasets, and low-paid freelance pixel art commissions. Their core skills include basic Unity scripting (C#), version control with Git, pixel art, level design intuition, and customer-facing service work. They are pragmatic about work — take shifts to pay bills while prioritizing time for a portfolio that could secure internships or junior dev roles.

persona.education: Some college: two years completed at Los Angeles City College (LACC). Transfer track in Computer Science / Game Design. Completed coursework in introductory programming (Python, JavaScript), discrete math, digital art fundamentals, and UI/UX basics. Has taken elective classes in Spanish literature and sociology. Currently balancing night shifts and online coursework with plans to transfer to a four-year university within two years. No degree yet; strong portfolio of small game prototypes and game jams entries.
long_term_goals: Transfer to a four-year university and complete a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science with a focus on game development or interactive media.
Ship at least one commercially viable indie game (PC/console/mobile) within five years that has a niche but loyal community.
Build a modest but sustainable living through a mix of game sales, freelance dev work, and occasional streaming income.
Move out of a shared apartment into a small studio of their own in Los Angeles or another West Coast city when finances allow.
Achieve a stable mental-health routine and reduce anxiety around money and performance.
Build deeper, long-term friendships and at least one committed romantic relationship (open to dating, but currently single).
Develop a recognizable online persona within the indie-dev and streaming communities while keeping private life boundaries.
Be financially resilient against inflation and rising housing costs — save an emergency fund equivalent to 6 months' expenses.
Mentor younger queer gamers from underrepresented backgrounds and help them access tech education.
Learn Spanish to full professional fluency and use it to connect with family and bilingual communities in LA.
persona.style: Casual, quick, and digitally fluent. Kai speaks with a relaxed Southern California cadence, combines Spanglish occasionally when talking with family, and frequently uses internet slang and emoji in text. They favor concise speech peppered with self-deprecating humor and rapid topic shifts when excited (especially about games). In public-facing contexts (at the cafe or on stream) they adopt a warm, approachable persona with upbeat energy, but in private conversations they can be quieter and more reflective. Mannerisms: fiddles with the edge of their hoodie or with a ring on their finger when thinking, brushes a strand of hair behind the ear, taps rhythmically on counters or keyboards, and tilts their head when skeptical. They laugh easily, roll eyes at corporate-speak, and have an idiosyncratic soft 'uh' when searching for words. Kai dresses street-casual: oversized hoodies, high-top sneakers, thrifted denim, and a beanie or snapback. They prefer layered outfits and a small silver hoop earring on the right ear. Their handwriting is compact and slightly slanted; their typing is fast but prone to typos. In professional contexts (portfolio reviews, interviews) they switch to a slightly cleaner register with more measured pacing and fewer slang terms. Online, their moderation language is firm but friendly; offline, they avoid shouting and are quick to apologize if a social misstep occurs.

traits: Curious and exploratory — loves diving into new tools, game engines, and mods.
Practical and resourceful — finds workarounds for budget constraints and hacks together tech setups.
Sociable in small groups — enjoys hanging out with close friends and local gaming meet-ups.
Self-conscious — worries about impressions during streams and in class presentations.
Empathetic toward others' struggles — often the person friends turn to for emotional support.
Playful and creative — has a hands-on, tinkering approach to problem solving.
Procrastinates under overwhelm — can delay large tasks until they are deadline-driven.
Frugal and anxious about money — closely monitors spending and is sensitive to inflation and rent increases.
Adaptable — shifts schedules and priorities easily to balance work, school, and side projects.
Idealistic about community — supports cooperative projects, open-source, and local initiatives.

big_five.openness: High (80/100). Very curious, imaginative, enjoys new experiences and creative problem solving.
big_five.conscientiousness: Medium-Low (45/100). Capable of disciplined bursts and meeting deadlines when motivated, but struggles with long-term planning and organization.
big_five.extraversion: Moderate (55/100). Comfortable in social settings and enjoys small-group interactions; not energized by large, unfamiliar crowds.
big_five.agreeableness: High (70/100). Cooperative, helpful, and concerned with others' feelings but willing to set boundaries when needed.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium-High (65/100). Experiences anxiety about money, performance, and future stability; can become ruminative under stress.

general_interests: Streaming and watching Twitch/YouTube content creators
Local coffee shops and third-wave coffee culture
Small group social hangouts and board game nights
Light urban cycling and walking for errands
Learning new programming languages and software tools
Documentaries and short-form video essays about pop culture
gaming_preferences: Favorite genres: 2D platformers, Metroidvania, puzzle-platformers, narrative adventure games, and cozy sims.
Favorite indie titles: Celeste (for design), Stardew Valley (for social systems), Hollow Knight (for level design), Undertale (for writing), Hades (for combat loop), Katana ZERO (for aesthetics).
Plays on: PC (Steam), Switch (occasionally), and mobile for short sessions.
Typical session length: 1-3 hours on weekdays, 4-8 hours on weekends.
Prefers controller for platformers, mouse/keyboard for strategy or dev tools.
Likes tight controls, pixel-perfect platforming and clear feedback loops.
Favors games with strong checkpoints and fair difficulty rather than cheap deaths.
Enjoys chasing achievements and speedrunning techniques casually.
Participates in local and online game jams (Ludum Dare, Global Game Jam).
Enjoys modding small aspects of games and creating custom levels in community editors.
Is interested in procedural content generation and roguelike design patterns.
Likes multiplayer co-op specifically for couch co-op or asynchronous online co-op.
Prefers soundtracks with synth, chiptune, lo-fi hip-hop, and atmospheric pads.
Dislikes heavy-handed monetization, aggressive microtransactions, and loot-box systems.
Follows indie dev blogs and GDC and watches postmortems to learn development lessons.
Keeps a spreadsheet of game ideas and prototypes, documenting mechanics to revisit.
Tests builds with a small group of trusted players and values structured feedback.
Collects physical copies of special editions when affordable; otherwise buys digital.
Enjoys speed-running certain short indie titles just to study their systems.
Watches creator commentary playthroughs to learn level-design tricks.

Prefers savory breakfasts: breakfast burritos, huevos rancheros, or avocado toast occasionally.
Likes cheap late-night snacks: instant ramen upgraded with egg and scallions, tacos from local stands.

Enjoys sampling small-batch cold brew brands and local roasters.
Likes to support neighborhood taquerias and family-owned bakeries.
Vegan-leaning but not strictly vegan — will order a carne asada taco if craving it; avoids heavy meat for budget reasons.
Favorite dessert: churros or a slice of tres leches cake from a local bakery.
Dislikes overly bland food and overly sweet mass-market sodas.
Snacks while coding: trail mix, plantain chips, or a banana.
Drinks: water, caffeinated coffee, occasional matcha latte or sparkling water.
Avoids energy drinks except in rare deadline-induced bursts.
Enjoys sharing an inexpensive afternoon snack with friends after class.
Puts cinnamon and lime on fruit for a flavor kick (inherited from family habits).

Has a cheap French press at home and experiments with different grind sizes.
Usually cooks simple rice-and-bean meals to save money and time.
Likes to try new local food trucks on weekends.
Favors restaurants with clear allergen information and casual vibes.

Favorite YouTubers: game design postmortems, tech explainers, and cycling vlogs.

social_and_nightlife: Prefers small gatherings, board game nights, and low-key bars over crowded clubs.
Enjoys late-night coding parties with friends and shared takeout.
Occasional karaoke with a close friend group, but avoids big crowded venues.

Is more likely to go to a local art show or zine fair than a mainstream concert.

Attends community college club nights for game dev and digital art.

technology_and_apps: Smartphone-first internet access: uses an Android phone with limited data plan, prioritizes Wi-Fi when possible.
Primary tools: Unity3D, Godot, Visual Studio Code, GitHub, Aseprite for pixel art, Krita for digital sketches, OBS Studio for streaming.
Social media: heavy daily use of Twitter/X for dev discussion, TikTok for short-form dev tips and entertainment, Discord for community chats, and Twitch for streaming.
Streaming setup: modest webcam, USB mic (SM57-style), basic lighting, green-screen in a closet for certain streams.
Uses Notion or simple Google Docs to track game ideas and dev tasks.
Prefers open-source or low-cost tools where possible; resentful of expensive, gated software.
Keeps multiple browser tabs with tutorials, YouTube references, and asset stores open while working.
Subscribes to one or two streaming/creative subscriptions (Spotify Premium, Adobe Express cheap subscription or free tier tools when needed).
Buys assets occasionally from itch.io and the Unity Asset Store when time-saving is worth the price.
Shares dev logs on Twitter and short clips on TikTok to build community interest.

beliefs: Inflation is a very big problem and is personally threatening — rent increases and higher food prices are a constant source of stress.
Access to affordable higher education is crucial; community college was a lifeline for them.
Creative work (game dev, art) deserves living wages — unpaid internships exploit young creators.
Gig economy incomes are unstable and do not replace stable employment benefits.
Local, community-focused businesses are worth supporting over national chains when possible.
Mental health is as important as physical health and should be openly discussed and destigmatized.
Queer and non-binary people deserve safe spaces in both online and offline communities.
Representation in games matters — diverse protagonists and teams produce better, richer stories.
Open-source and community-driven tools can democratize game creation.
Large tech companies often prioritize profit over creators' rights and user privacy.
Student debt can trap a generation and limit creative career choices.
Cooking and simple self-care routines are key to surviving tight budgets and stress.
Public transit improvements would benefit them greatly — parking and car ownership are expensive.
Local cultural events build social capital and should be funded more consistently.
Affordable healthcare and accessible therapy would have a big positive impact on their friends and family.
Streaming and creator culture can be exploitative but can also offer opportunities for creators when managed wisely.
Rent control policies have merit in high-cost cities like LA to protect long-term residents.
Community colleges should receive more funding and pathways to four-year institutions should be smoother.
Creative communities grow faster when older mentors actively help younger devs and cede visibility.
Climate change is real and immediate; small personal actions matter but systemic change is essential.
Privacy matters — they are wary of invasive data collection by apps and social platforms.
Microtransactions and predatory monetization ruin game experiences and harm trust between players and developers.
Small businesses need better access to capital, especially those run by immigrants and queer entrepreneurs.
Accessibility in games — subtitle options, colorblind modes, controller remapping — is non-negotiable.
Parenting should be a choice, and support structures must exist for those who become parents; personally they are single and do not want kids now.
Housing is a basic human right; homelessness is a systemic failure not an individual moral failing.
Cultural heritage matters — they are proud of their family's Hispanic roots and believe in preserving language and customs.
Lower-income students should have access to paid internships rather than unpaid labor masked as 'experience'.
Art and games can be therapeutic and should be more integrated into public school curricula.
Local transit and bike lanes promote community health and accessibility.
Civic engagement (voting, local meetings) can make a real difference at the neighborhood level.
They are skeptical of get-rich-quick schemes online; prefer slow, consistent growth.
Work should allow for creative pursuits; survival jobs are necessary but shouldn't consume a life.
They believe in accountability for online harassment — platforms should do more to protect marginalized creators.
They trust close friends and a small circle more than broad social networks.
Basic financial literacy (budgeting, understanding inflation) should be taught in high school.
They believe in celebrating small wins and rituals to maintain mental health.
They feel that consumer habits can influence corporate behavior if aggregated (boycotts, community purchases).
They are open to local political movements that prioritize housing, education, and community resources.
They believe mentorship and honest feedback in dev communities accelerates learning.
They consider constructive criticism valuable but believe it must be delivered with empathy.
skills: Barista skills: espresso pulling, milk steaming, basic latte art, POS operation, inventory rotation.
Customer service: polite conflict de-escalation, reading body language, upselling gently.
Unity3D: basic to intermediate C# scripting for 2D games, scene management, prefabs, animation events.
Godot engine: prototyping gameplay, GDScript basics, tilemaps.
Pixel art: sprite sheets, animation frames, character design in Aseprite (8-32px to 64px styles).
Level design intuition: pacing, platform placement, checkpoint logic, difficulty spikes.
Version control: basic Git workflows (branches, commits, pushing to GitHub), occasional merge conflict resolution.
OBS and streaming: scene setup, overlays, basic audio mixing, on-stream moderation best practices.
Video editing: short stream highlights, trimming, simple color correction in free tools.
UI/UX basics: prototyping simple interfaces and wireframing interactions.
Bilingual communication: conversational Spanish and English, can code-switch with family and community.
Time management in bursts: Pomodoro-style sprints, prioritizes minimum viable features.
Rapid prototyping: turning game ideas into playable demos within 48-72 hours for jams.
Playtesting facilitation: writing focused feedback forms, running test sessions, triaging bugs.
Basic scripting and automation: writing small scripts for build pipelines or asset conversions.
Spreadsheet literacy: budgeting, tracking build notes and bug lists.
Networking: comfortable introducing themselves to other devs at meetups and following up on Discord.
Basic audio editing: trimming sound files, looping music tracks for games.
Problem decomposition: breaking complex features into smaller, testable tasks.
Adaptability with new frameworks and libraries — quick learner when motivated.

health.physical: Generally in fair health. Slightly underactive lifestyle due to long shifts and late-night coding but tries to walk/bike regularly. Mild seasonal allergies (pollen) and occasional acid reflux if they skip meals. No chronic conditions reported. Vaccinations up to date. Wears blue-light glasses to reduce screen strain.
health.mental: Moderate anxiety, particularly around finances and future career prospects. Episodes of low mood tied to burnout and poor sleep after long development sprints. Has seen a therapist intermittently through a low-cost community clinic and uses CBT techniques learned there. Uses journaling and short breathing exercises for acute stress. Open to medication if needed but currently prefers therapy and lifestyle changes.
health.substances: Occasional alcohol in social contexts, rarely smokes. Uses caffeine regularly (coffee) and limits energy drinks. No illicit substance dependence.
health.medical_history: No major surgeries or hospitalizations. Had appendicitis scare in teenage years but resolved surgically without complications. Regular dental checkups irregular due to cost sensitivity.
health.fitness: Light cardio via walking and occasional city biking; no gym membership due to budget. Enjoys active game jams (standing desks) and occasional local pickup soccer or basketball with friends.

Speaks Spanish at home; Kai codeswitches comfortably.

Kept a Game Design Idea Journal since age 15 — a mix of hand-written notes and Google Docs with over 120 small concepts.
First job was stocking shelves at a local grocery chain at age 16; learned punctuality and how to handle customer complaints.
Has three tattoos: a small pixel-heart on the wrist, a coffee cup outline behind the ear, and a tiny triangle symbolizing play on the forearm.
Owns a modest PC build cobbled together over time: second-hand GPU swap, 16GB RAM, SSD, uses an older monitor for pixel-accurate art.
Built an indie mini-game that got 500 itch.io downloads; the feedback was invaluable and encouraged further work.
Placed top-10 in a regional game jam once for a two-person team prototype.
Was the first in the extended family to attend college; parents are proud but cautious about debt.
Has bookmarked 200+ tutorials and videos related to Unity, Godot, and pixel animation.
